body: IN 1992, THE TRUMPETER Dave Douglas was on a tour of one-nighters with a band led by the clarinetist Don Byron, and the group came through Florence. The day of the concert, Mr. Douglas visited the Santa Maria del Fiore Cathedral, in the center of town, and later that day read the tale of its construction. The story is this: In the 13th century,

body: Ruth W. Messinger turned to public transportation yesterday in a final 19-hour quest for votes, riding 10 subway lines and the Staten Island ferry to campaign in all boroughs. title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CHALLENGER; By Subway, Ferry and Bus, Seeking Votes

body: A Brooklyn teen-ager leaning against the emergency door of an overcrowded bus chartered by a church, was critically injured yesterday afternoon when she fell onto a highway, the authorities said. Maribell Isales, 16, of Red Hook, was listed in critical but stable condition last night at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. Miss Isales was
title: Bus Door Fails, Throwing Rider Onto Highway

body: Watching Angel Rodriguez enter the Sunset Park Senior Citizen Center is something like witnessing the second coming of Elvis. Men shout and offer handshakes; women swoon and demand besos, or kisses. Mr. Rodriguez, 40, circulates, giving hugs, besos and advice, even joking about his bulging belly with a group of women. This, said Mr. Rodriguez, the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE -- In 2 Corners of City, a Surge in Hispanic Power; Brooklyn Area May Put Puerto Rican on Council

body: Primaries are the real elections in many heavily Democratic parts of Brooklyn, and next Tuesday's ballots will feature an unusual number of competitive races for New York City Council seats. body: A few weeks before the stock market surged past 8,000 for the first time, James and Tiffany Palmer ventured into the Manhattan real-estate market with a modest goal: an extra bedroom for Whitney, their newborn daughter. title: With Fierce Competition for Homes, Minutes to Spend Millions

body: For generations, the consolidation of New York City in 1897 was known in Brooklyn as ''the Great Mistake.'' By a margin of just 277 votes (some say ballot boxes were stuffed), Brooklyn, the nation's fourth-largest city, had voted to give up its proud and independent history. Foes of the merger predicted that forever after, Brooklynites would live
title: The Legendary Dodgers Aren't Coming Back Yet, But the Borough Is

body: To the Editor: You fairly presented the problems facing the Flames, but failed to hold the Diocese of Brooklyn's feet to the fire on their refusal to allow this successful community team to continue playing. What better use for a Catholic school gymnasium than doing ''a lot of good for a lot of poor kids''? RAY PALERMO Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn
title: Article on Basketball Team Is Disservice to Bensonhurst
